content.content: Sentence Summary Should MKR holders guide targets for bear-market expense cuts via an on-chain vote?  Background Following our presentation on the latest G&R call, we dove deeper on our cash runway discussion from last week and put together various scenarios to calculate Maker’s runway in the event of sustained unprofitability. After months of resilience, and despite still technically booking significant profits on the back of unfortunate liquidations, it is looking more and more likely that Maker will start running cash unprofitable months when measured purely on a recurring revenue basis, at our current burn rates. Hopefully the below pages will help the community narrow down closer to what that position really is and represents.  Slide1800×554 36.8 KB   Slide2800×554 97.7 KB   Slide3800×554 99.2 KB   Slide4800×554 101 KB   Slide5800×554 75.8 KB  On three scenarios of varying degrees of bearishness, we are calculating what the effective number of operating years would be available with three different levels of spending  Spending assumptions  On-chain actual cash movements CU reported expenses Maximum approved spend from budget process   On-chain actual cash movements These are real cash movements from the DAO to CU multisigs. However, often they capture various weeks or even months of working capital so they are subject to phasing considerations. In our monthly reports we rely on this figure for the sake of conservatism.  CU reported expenses Every month, most CUs report actual expenses by type. This is closer to an accrual view of expenses and creates a delta to on-chain transactions. However, it also depends on self-reporting from CUs.  Maximum approved spend from budgets This is the theoretical maximum that the DAO has authorized the CUs to spend. Our current run-rate is well under this figure, but is worth keeping in mind for conservatism when it comes to calculating runways.  Interest income from short-term bonds On top of this, interest income from our initiatives to invest in short-term bonds through Baillie Gifford and BlackRock will significantly extend our runway.  Signal Request Poll If this Signal Request is approved, the on-chain poll will feature ranked-choice options between several options. This Signal Request will run for one week rather than two given the urgency triggered by market conditions.     Signal Request Options Pro Con     A. Yes (MKR holders should take a view) Provides maximum level of discretion to MKR holders around use of cash and strategies to survive the bear-market MKR holders may not be updated with operational minutiae and might not be equipped to make the most informed decision   B. No (MKR holders should not take a view) Proactive engagement within the DAO is the best tool to select the target level of profitability to target MKR holders would be cut out from a crucial decision regarding the use of DAO funds    SR Start/End Date: 2022-06-23T17:00:00Z→2022-06-30T17:00:00Z The on-chain poll would be framed as follows: What target level of Recurring Net Protocol Income profitability (defined as rNPI / Recurring Revenues averaged over a preceding 3 calendar month period, excluding MKR vesting and liquidation income) should the DAO set in order to drive budget cuts?  Positive (> 5%) Break-even (±5%) Negative (minimum 3 years of runway at any time) No change      On-Chain Options Pro Con     Positive (>5%) Would continue accumulating dai in the surplus buffer and increase the short-term book value per MKR token May force the DAO to make cuts in CUs with significant business continuity impact and reduce the ability of CUs to maximize the opportunity at the end of the bear   Break-even (±5%) Would allow a small amount of flexibility to account for market fluctuations May occasionally have a negative impact on the surplus buffer in extended periods of narrow unprofitability   Negative (minimum 3 years of runway at any time) Allows a flexible framework for maintaining investment while still imposing a hard cutoff to control spending Increases the possibility of extended drawdowns on the surplus buffer        Should MKR Holders select a target level of rNPI profitability to guide budget cuts?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters

content.content: Opting for No here–usually when an organization makes across-the-board-cuts there is a percentage set and then the decision makers are asked to develop proposals for achieving those cuts. In this case it would be the Facilitators within their Core Units. This will provide facilitators flexibility to make the cuts where they will do the least damage to their ongoing operations. And if their budget has spam/pork the facilitators can cut that first. Similar to what you are proposing here, the DAO/MKR token owners can decide the level of reduction each Core Unit should incur. It can be ask to cut budgets at levels of 10%, 20%, and 30% via an on-chain poll (TOL). This process will allow facilitators to evaluate the degree of the cut that can be sustained. And if CU cannot accept such percentage of cuts, they can make a push for earning higher revenues, similar to what the MetaDAOs (EndGame) will be able to accomplish in the near future. All-in-all the way to pull yourself out of a hole, is to create opportunities and sell your way out.

content.content: I appreciate you putting analysis and SR together for the DAO. I know it takes a lot of work. A couple of questions:   The SR assumes we are making “budget cuts.” Is there a possibility this is not the case?   The SR is using rNPI over the past three months as a basis for “budget cuts.” Is this the best number to use when considering these adjustments could have a significant impact on the ability/longevity for CUs to operate?   When you look at “start running cash unprofitable months,” it appears there is a bias that is this not acceptable. Some times with budgets, there are “vanity” metrics to make something look good and I wonder if this is one of those areas? Do we care if we have a negative month(s) as long as our runway is solid?   We do have ongoing liquidation revenue. Is there a way to normalize this and add it to our expected income?   Can’t we expect some income from short-term bonds? It seems like the model isn’t accurate if we don’t include this in the base case. The comments suggest “will significantly extend our runway.” This is material for DAO revenues.   In the Signal Request Poll, it’s a little confusing in the wording. So I am clear, this is an offchain poll that if it is YES, will move to an onchain poll based upon the framing listed. If the poll is NO, you are suggesting “Proactive engagement.” I’m not exactly sure what that means and don’t see why MKR holders would be “cut.” As a suggestion, I would remove the Pro/Con section as it’s an opinion and reads biased to me. For example, I don’t agree that a Pro is this “provides maximum level of discretion.” It’s quite debatable. Btw, I’m not asking to have that debate here…just pointing out the difference in an opinion and factual based data.   Overall, the information in this SR seems to make assumptions based upon a super conservative look at our finances then attempts to apply a formula, based upon a point in time look at the DAO finances, in order to make “budget cuts.” I hope the DAO can find a way not to use a sledge hammer to drive in a finishing nail with our budgeting exercise.

content.content: monkey.irish:  The SR assumes we are making “budget cuts.” Is there a possibility this is not the case?   You could expand the negative option a little here by asking how long we would be willing to stay negative at higher monthly losses than a 3 year runway would call for.  You could also specify a surplus buffer level that you do not want to drop under and limit cuts based on expected timelines for new revenue.     monkey.irish:  When you look at “start running cash unprofitable months,” it appears there is a bias that is this not acceptable. Some times with budgets, there are “vanity” metrics to make something look good and I wonder if this is one of those areas? Do we care if we have a negative month(s) as long as our runway is solid?   Just an opinion, but I think there is reason to bias toward profitability.  For MKR, the SB affects more than just runway.  It also affects risk.  Every month there is a loss heightens our risks and lowers the amount of capital we can put at risk in the future.  (I guess people who want to do a capital raise can jump in here and say we can always borrow more…)  To be fair, having less collateral also lowers our risk but that’s not what we’re aiming for right?     monkey.irish:  We do have ongoing liquidation revenue. Is there a way to normalize this and add it to our expected income?   We’ve gone from 3.4B DAI generated from non-stablecoins to under 1.3B in less than 2 months.  I don’t think there’s much more liquidation revenue to be had so you can pretty much count that out.     monkey.irish:  Can’t we expect some income from short-term bonds? It seems like the model isn’t accurate if we don’t include this in the base case. The comments suggest “will significantly extend our runway.” This is material for DAO revenues.   If Monetalis efforts work out and tens of millions of new recurring revenue are within grasp, it should certainly be considered.  I don’t think anyone would mind running negative for a few months if we would be positive thereafter.  But I expect there are low-value items that could be cut without too much long term impact and it’s not a bad thing to spend some time to focus on capital efficiency in the current environment.

content.content: monkey.irish:  The SR assumes we are making “budget cuts.” Is there a possibility this is not the case?   Ultimately that is up to MKR holders and Delegates but given the extremely high discrepancy between approved budgets and actual spend, my sense is that budgets in aggregate should be reduced. If Core Units with large unspent budgets were unable to invest such funds during a bull market, pragmatically it seems unlikely that they will in a bear market. With that said, the DAO may decide to reallocate capital and some Core Unit budgets could be increased.     monkey.irish:  When you look at “start running cash unprofitable months,” it appears there is a bias that is this not acceptable. Some times with budgets, there are “vanity” metrics to make something look good and I wonder if this is one of those areas? Do we care if we have a negative month(s) as long as our runway is solid?   The largest MKR holder has expressed his desire that the Maker protocol should be running profitably, today. There are certainly other large holders with opposing views and it will be up to the DAO collectively to make this decision.     monkey.irish:  We do have ongoing liquidation revenue. Is there a way to normalize this and add it to our expected income?   As @Traster_Tray alluded to, liquidation income is not something we feel the protocol can rely on especially with how far liquidatable collateral has fallen.     monkey.irish:  Can’t we expect some income from short-term bonds? It seems like the model isn’t accurate if we don’t include this in the base case. The comments suggest “will significantly extend our runway.” This is material for DAO revenues.   Assumptions for short-term bond income are included in the model, in the second to last slide titled, “Cash Burn after adjusting for BlackRock and Baillie Gifford”     monkey.irish:  Overall, the information in this SR seems to make assumptions based upon a super conservative look at our finances then attempts to apply a formula, based upon a point in time look at the DAO finances, in order to make “budget cuts.” I hope the DAO can find a way not to use a sledge hammer to drive in a finishing nail with our budgeting exercise.   This is a mischaracterization in my view - the cash flow analysis simply presents the existing run-rates and downside potential under continued collateral asset price pressure. As my colleague @SebVentures likes to say, “all models are wrong, but some are useful.” Such model was provided to illustrate to the community, directionally, what would happen to the Maker protocol’s cash runway. It is by no means a forecast and does not intend to be. Every MKR holder and delegate can make their own assumptions and express their views on chain if they support operating the protocol based on such metrics.

content.content: I realize this is a challenging process for the DAO and I want to be supportive as possible. As a general statement, these exercises start with a set of assumption and data is provided to support those assumptions. Data is inherently biased so it’s important to ensure what we say is accurate and represents the shared understanding of the community. I believe there is a way to optimize our budgets and I plan to be part of that. I’d rather see a proposal from the community on next steps. This SR ends the conversation with “in order to drive budget cuts.” I think that is a tactic in a much larger picture. content.content: SF serves at the will of MKR holders and the largest one has been expressing, repeatedly, a desire for budget cuts and a return to profitability. This is in opposition to my personal view, which I’ve also expressed publicly and privately - I believe value will be maximized by running the protocol at a modest loss in the near term to lay the foundation necessary to grow revenues more sustainably longer term, but it is the MKR holders’ decision to make. Nevertheless, if MKR holders want budget cuts and profitability, SF will help facilitate such goals given our mandate and request from the largest MKR holder to do so. SF has no agenda and I would recommend you speak with the largest MKR holder directly if you are opposed to budget cuts. We also encourage the community to present proposals.

content.content: Aes:  largest one has been expressing, repeatedly, a desire for budget cuts and a return to profitability   Using this important point to direct my comments to the community. From the calls I’ve attended, even that MKR holder would like wider participation. In the last round of voting, I saw 200k+ MKR voted on proposals. There is an opportunity for the community to respond and partner with SF on DAO growth and costs. “Adjusting budgets and achieving profitability” is a challenging task and there are many ways to go about it especially with growth organizations. Is a “cold process-driven parameter” what the DAO needs to guide this exercise? Given how some of the End Game affiliations are forming, it seems like this is a hot topic and I think there are a few community members that know about startup finance. No need to wait for party formation, voter committees, etc. Get involved today. Perfect is the enemy of good. It’s also acceptable to delegate projects like this to core units. Without community input, feedback, and participation, that’s the default case. If you have other ideas, please get involved. @Recognized-Delegates #whales #vcs

content.content: I voted yes, and I believe we should target break even minimum for Maker Core (and I believe there are still critical core expenses missing, such as higher delegate compensation and oracle node security expenses). But in the case that we go ahead with MetaDAOs I believe we can make an exception in the short term (1-2 years) and instead burn through a portion of the surplus buffer in order to transition parts of the workforce that cannot be sustained by the core to the MetaDAOs as internal MetaDAO core units, so that all the incredible talent doesn’t go to waste and on the contrary we can use it to create much more value and growth for the protocol and ecosystem.
